clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is famous for its iconic red telephone booths and double-decker buses.
Home to a giant Ferris wheel on the River Thames.
fun_fact: The London Underground is the oldest underground railway network in the world, dating back to 1863.
Despite its reputation for rain, London actually has less annual rainfall than Rome, Barcelona, and even Sydney.
trivia: The Great Fire of London in 1666 destroyed over 13,000 houses but resulted in improved building regulations.
The clock tower commonly referred to as 'Big Ben' is actually named Elizabeth Tower; Big Ben is the bell inside.

clues: This city features an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
Visitors often throw coins into a famous fountain to ensure their return.
fun_fact: About €3,000 is thrown into the Trevi Fountain each day and is collected to fund a supermarket for the city's poor.
Rome has more than 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
trivia: Ancient Romans used to clean their teeth with urine due to its ammonia content.
The Roman Colosseum could hold up to 80,000 spectators for its events.

clues: This city features a famous opera house with sail-shaped roofs.
The largest natural harbor in the world is located here.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House has over one million roof tiles covering approximately 1.62 hectares.
It took 16 years to build the Opera House, 10 years longer than expected.
trivia: Sydney's Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its distinctive arch-based design.
Approximately 40% of Sydney's population was born overseas, making it one of the world's most multicultural cities.

clues: This city is located near one of the seven wonders of the ancient world.
The oldest and largest film industry in the Arab world is based here.
fun_fact: Cairo is home to Al-Azhar University, one of the oldest universities in the world, established in 970 CE.
The city's name 'Al-Qahirah' in Arabic means 'The Vanquisher' or 'The Conqueror'.
trivia: Despite being in a desert country, Cairo rarely experiences rain but when it does, it can cause significant flooding due to poor drainage systems.
The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for nearly 4,000 years.

clues: Famous for a giant statue of Christ with outstretched arms overlooking the city.
Home to one of the world's most famous beaches, renowned for its distinctive sidewalk pattern.
fun_fact: The Rio Carnival is the world's largest carnival, with approximately 2 million people per day on the streets.
Rio de Janeiro briefly served as the capital of the Portuguese Empire from 1808 to 1821.
trivia: The famous Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning several times a year and has special lightning rods installed.
The iconic black and white wave pattern on Copacabana Beach sidewalks was designed by Brazilian landscape architect Roberto Burle Marx.

clues: This city's main square is known for its colorful onion-domed cathedral.
Home to the largest fortress in the world that serves as the official residence of the country's president.
fun_fact: The Moscow Metro is one of the busiest and most beautiful subway systems in the world, with stations decorated like palaces.
Dogs in Moscow have learned to use the subway system to travel around the city independently.
trivia: Moscow's Red Square is not named for the color of its bricks or communist associations but from the Russian word 'krasniy' which once meant 'beautiful'.
The Kremlin walls were originally made of wood and were rebuilt in red brick during the late 15th century.

clues: This city is home to the world's tallest building.
Features artificial islands shaped like a palm tree when viewed from above.
fun_fact: Dubai has the world's only 7-star hotel, although the rating isn't officially recognized by any international organization.
Only about 15% of Dubai's population are native Emiratis; the rest are expatriates.
trivia: Dubai Police's fleet includes luxury cars like Lamborghinis, Ferraris, and Bugattis.
The city has virtually no address system – locations are described by nearby landmarks.

clues: This city-state features a hotel with an infinity pool that appears to be floating above the skyline.
Known for strict rules against littering and chewing gum.
fun_fact: Singapore's Changi Airport has its own butterfly garden with more than 1,000 butterflies and a 40-foot indoor waterfall.
The national anthem of Singapore is printed in microtext on the back of their $1,000 bill.
trivia: Singapore has one of the world's lowest crime rates, making it one of the safest cities globally.
The Singapore Sling cocktail was created at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore in the early 1900s.

clues: This city features a famous unfinished cathedral designed by Antoni Gaudí.
Known for its distinctive modernist architecture and vibrant street life.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Família has been under construction since 1882 and is not expected to be completed until 2026.
Barcelona's main boulevard, La Rambla, was once a sewage-filled stream outside the city walls.
trivia: Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 7 of which were designed by Antoni Gaudí.
The city is the only one in the world to receive a Royal Gold Medal for architecture from the Royal Institute of British Architects.

clues: This city is built on more than 100 small islands and has canals instead of streets.
Famous for its gondolas and annual carnival featuring elaborate masks.
fun_fact: Venice has about 400 foot bridges and 170 boat canals, with the Grand Canal being the largest and most famous.
The city is sinking at a rate of approximately 1-2mm per year.
trivia: Venetians once painted their homes in bright colors so fishermen could identify their homes from the sea.
The profession of gondolier is passed down from father to son, and there are only about 400 licensed gondoliers in Venice.

clues: This city has more canals than Venice and more bridges than Paris.
Famous for its narrow houses, bicycles, and historical museums.
fun_fact: Amsterdam houses are narrow because property taxes were once based on the width of the facade facing the canal.
There are approximately 881,000 bicycles in Amsterdam, which is more than the number of residents.
trivia: The narrowest house in Amsterdam is just 2.02 meters (6 feet 7 inches) wide, while the narrowest facade is only 1 meter wide.
Many of Amsterdam's canal houses are tilted forward intentionally - this design allowed goods to be hoisted up without hitting the facade.

clues: This city sits on two continents divided by a strait.
Once known as Constantinople, it was the capital of multiple empires.
fun_fact: Istanbul is the only city in the world that spans two continents: Europe and Asia.
The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world with over 4,000 shops.
trivia: The Hagia Sophia, now a mosque, was originally built as a cathedral in 537 CE and was the world's largest cathedral for nearly 1,000 years.
Istanbul has been the capital of three great empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.

clues: This city has a temple with a massive reclining Buddha statue.
Known for floating markets and street food culture.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world with 169 characters.
The city is sinking at a rate of 2-3 centimeters per year due to excessive groundwater pumping.
trivia: Bangkok has more than 400 wats (Buddhist temples) scattered throughout the city.
The Thai currency, the baht, is illegal to take out of the country and considered more valuable within Thailand than outside.

clues: This city sits at the foot of a famous flat-topped mountain.
Known for its stunning beaches and nearby penguin colonies.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has its own 'tablecloth' – a cloud formation that drapes over the mountain when the temperature drops.
Cape Town is known for having four distinct seasons in a single day due to its unique geography and weather patterns.
trivia: Cape Town is home to the first heart transplant which was performed by Dr. Christiaan Barnard in 1967.
The Castle of Good Hope in Cape Town is the oldest surviving colonial building in South Africa, built between 1666 and 1679.

clues: This city was built on a lake and has been sinking since its founding.
Home to the most museums of any city in the Americas.
fun_fact: Mexico City is built on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the ancient Aztec capital, and much of it sits on a drained lake bed.
The city has the largest concentration of museums in the world, with over 150 official museums.
trivia: Mexico City's Chapultepec Park is one of the largest city parks in the Western Hemisphere, nearly twice the size of Central Park in New York.
The Metro system serves 4.6 million people daily and has multiple stations with Aztec artifacts displayed inside.

clues: This city is home to the world's largest film industry.
Features a famous arch monument on the waterfront that was built to commemorate a royal visit.
fun_fact: Mumbai's dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 home-cooked lunches to office workers every day with remarkable precision and almost no errors.
The city was originally a cluster of seven islands that were joined through land reclamation projects in the 19th century.
trivia: Mumbai's Dharavi is one of the largest slums in Asia but also one of the most productive, with an annual economic output of approximately $1 billion.
The name 'Bollywood' comes from combining Bombay (Mumbai's former name) with Hollywood.

clues: This city was once divided by a famous wall that fell in 1989.
Known for its vibrant street art scene and techno music clubs.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice with over 1,700 bridges spanning its many canals and waterways.
There's a currywurst museum in Berlin dedicated to the city's most popular street food.
trivia: Berlin's main train station, Hauptbahnhof, is the largest crossing station in Europe, spanning five levels.
The Berlin Wall was actually two walls with a 'death strip' in between where guards could shoot escapees.

clues: This city is known as the 'Paris of South America' for its European architecture.
Home to a colorful neighborhood famous for tango dancing.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has the highest concentration of bookstores per person of any city in the world.
The city's main avenue, 9 de Julio Avenue, is the widest avenue in the world with up to 16 lanes.
trivia: The Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aires, where Eva Perón is buried, is like a small city with streets and ornate mausoleums.
Buenos Aires was founded twice: first in 1536, then abandoned and refounded in 1580.

clues: This city is famous for its classical music heritage and opera houses.
Known for its coffee house culture and Sachertorte chocolate cake.
fun_fact: Vienna's central cemetery (Zentralfriedhof) is home to more than 3 million people, more than the living population of the city.
The snow globe was invented in Vienna in 1900 by surgical instrument maker Erwin Perzy.
trivia: Vienna has consistently been ranked as one of the world's most livable cities and has some of the world's best drinking water piped directly from the Alps.
The world's oldest zoo still in operation is located in Vienna, founded in 1752 as an imperial menagerie.

clues: This city is home to a famous tower that was once the world's tallest freestanding structure.
Known for its diverse population with over 200 ethnic groups speaking more than 140 languages.
fun_fact: Toronto has the longest street in the world according to the Guinness Book of World Records: Yonge Street stretches for 1,896 km (1,178 miles).
The city has more than 10 million trees, giving it the nickname 'The City Within a Park'.
trivia: Toronto's PATH is the largest underground shopping complex in the world with 30 km (19 miles) of shopping arcades.
The city is built on a series of ravines that create one of the largest urban forest systems in the world.

clues: This city is spread across 14 islands connected by 57 bridges.
Home to a museum dedicated to a 17th-century warship that sank on its maiden voyage.
fun_fact: Stockholm's subway system is known as the world's longest art gallery, with unique installations in almost every station.
The Stockholm archipelago consists of about 30,000 islands, islets, and skerries.
trivia: The Nobel Prize ceremony is held annually in Stockholm's Concert Hall, followed by a banquet in the City Hall.
Stockholm was the first city to introduce congestion charging in Europe, significantly reducing traffic in the city center.

clues: This city features ancient palaces alongside ultra-modern skyscrapers.
Known for its vibrant street food scene and 24-hour culture.
fun_fact: Seoul's Incheon International Airport has been rated the world's best airport multiple times and features a golf course, ice skating rink, and indoor gardens.
The city has the world's fastest average internet speed and free public Wi-Fi is available across much of the capital.
trivia: Seoul was almost completely destroyed during the Korean War but was rebuilt in just 50 years to become one of the world's most modern cities.
The iconic N Seoul Tower changes colors based on air quality readings in the city.

clues: This city is known for its ancient medina with narrow maze-like streets.
Famous for vibrant markets called souks and a central square filled with entertainers.
fun_fact: Almost all buildings in the old city of Marrakech are painted in a specific shade of red-orange, giving it the nickname 'Red City'.
The traditional riads (houses) feature interior gardens designed to provide natural air conditioning in the desert heat.
trivia: The tanneries of Marrakech still use medieval techniques to produce leather goods, with workers standing waist-deep in vats of dye.
The famous Jemaa el-Fnaa square transforms completely from day to night, from a marketplace to an open-air dining area with storytellers and musicians.
